results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 168]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows downhill, cross-country and slalom skiing at Mt Buller, Victoria, including the Women’s National Ski Competition in August 1947 and 1948 (according to notes on the donated original film can). There are good views including a horse drawn sled, snow fashion of the era and a ski lodge.

This film was originally made using 16mm film. Some of the footage is overexposed.

Selected highlights list
00:00:02:00 downhill ski race, various competitors filmed from a fixed camera position
00:02:40:00 views of snowed covered mountains
00:02:50:00 skiers in distance going downhill, possible slalom
00:03:46:00 better footage of downhill slalom
00:04:36:00 skiers walking uphill wearing skis, views of mountain and ski lodge
00:04:49:00 skiers walking uphill wearing skis
00:04:58:00 good footage of horse drawn sled
00:05:06:00 skiers walking wearing skis
00:06:50:00 group cross country skiing with sled
00:06:58:00 man strapped to sled (possibly injured or practising)
00:07:08:00 man gets off sled at ski lodge amid group of skiers
00:07:17:00 close up views of skiers at lodge showing fashions of the era
00:07:35:00 people riding horse drawn sled
00:07:44:00 downhill skiing
00:08:32:00 dining room in ski lodge full of diners (waitress in uniform)
00:09:03:00 mountain views
00:09:40:00 horse riding
00:10:38:00 man standing by car loaded with skis

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 152]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This short film shows small yachts sailing on Port Phillip Bay near Frankston, Victoria in 1969. Teams of 3 are shown sailing small wooden yachts and possibly racing. Some beach scenes are included.

This film was originally made using 16mm film. Much of the footage of the sailing is overexposed and slightly out of focus.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 57]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film captures a trip on the ‘Paddle Steamer Emmylou’ along the Murray River, NSW and Victoria, in 1982.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:04:00 Jess Gadsden and companions having lunch on the deck of the ‘Emmylou’
00:00:28:00 houses appear on on the riverbank
00:03:13:00 the ‘Emmylou’ flag being explained to passengers
00:03:14:00 buffet 1970s style
00:03:55:00 ‘Paddle Steamer Emmylou’ in full view
00:14:41:00 Jess Gadsden standing on the bank, looking at a weir on the Murray and waving at the camera
00:09:38:00 passengers assisting with loading wood onto the ‘Emmylou’

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 33]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film contains footage of the National Titles skiing competition at Thredbo in NSW. The end of the reel shows the end of games gathering where the skiiers (still with skis strapped on) are in fancy dress for the presentation of awards and drinking beers as the sun goes down.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:23:23:00 skiiers in fancy dress for awards

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 27]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film is the second of two that capture a family holiday to far north Queensland and the Great Barrier Reef in May, 1975.

The Gadsden family travel by yacht to visit a tropical shore, enjoy an evening barbeque, go scuba diving and bask in the sun. They then travel to the town of Kuranda by train going through some spectacular rainforest scenery on their way.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:22:00 passenger yacht ‘Tiki’ anchors off an island and lets down a rowboat.
00:00:40:00 wallabies and kangaroos join the travellers for lunch
00:00:59:00 a kangaroo eating bread from its paws
00:01:31:00 old coral and shells on a beach
00:02:00:00 various efforts to break open a coconut
00:03:07:00 eating the coconut
00:03:20:00 tropical flowers, banana trees, palms and views around the landscape
00:04:12:00 lunch being set up on the beach – cutting vegetables and a makeshift barbeque plate on the sand
00:04:23:00 entering the water for snorkelling
00:04:49:00 sausages and onion rings on the barbeque plate with flames underneath
00:05:34:00 serving food from the barbeque to the travellers
00:05:57:00 the travellers picnic on the beach
00:06:18:00 sunbathing on the beach
00:07:00:00 speeding across the water
00:07:05:00 pamphlet for ‘Cairns-Kuranda’ rail trip showing the route the travellers will follow.
00:07:25:00 lovely old train
00:07:45:00 passengers boarding a train at a rail station
00:07:54:00 views from the moving train - the track below, sugar cultivation and lush hills
00:08:23:00 ‘Redlynch’ rail station with glimpses of pot plants and ferns typical of Queensland
00:09:05:00 scenic views and waving children
00:09:25:00 view of the train snaking ahead
00:10:00:00 views of the lush landscape from a higher vantage point
00:10:25:00 the train travels through tunnels and close vegetation and local onlookers standing by the tracks
00:10:36:00 train travels over a lovely old wooden bridge as it rises higher into the forest covered hills
00:10:58:00 a waterfall
00:11:30:00 looking out over fields to the sea as the train keeps moving along
00:11:44:00 train travels past labourers – probably from sugar cane fields
00:12:00:00 a sign for ‘Barron Falls’
00:12:29:00 the camera inadvertently captures a fashion moment from the 1970s – long hair in low ‘pigtails’ tied with equally long green narrow ribbons
00:12:44:00 the Gadsden travellers looking out the train window
00:12:54:00 Jess Gadsden among other sightseers hopping back onto the train from a lookout point
00:13:20:00 coming into the picturesque Kuranda rail station filled with pot plants and foliage and views around the station
00:14:16:00 sign for ‘Kuranda’
00:14:33:00 the Gadsden travellers enjoy a beer whilst at Kuranda Station

00:09:25:00 view of the train snaking ahead
00:10:00:00 views of the lush landscape from a higher vantage point
00:10:25:00 the train travels through tunnels and close vegetation and local onlookers standing by the tracks
00:10:36:00 train travels over a lovely old wooden bridge as it rises higher into the forest covered hills
00:10:58:00 a waterfall
00:11:30:00 looking out over fields to the sea as the train keeps moving along
00:11:44:00 train travels past labourers – probably from sugar cane fields
00:12:00:00 a sign for ‘Barron Falls’
00:12:29:00 the camera inadvertently captures a fashion moment from the 1970s – long hair in low ‘pigtails’ tied with equally long green narrow ribbons
00:12:44:00 the Gadsden travellers looking out the train window
00:12:54:00 Jess Gadsden among other sightseers hopping back onto the train from a lookout point
00:13:20:00 coming into the picturesque Kuranda rail station filled with pot plants and foliage and views around the station
00:14:16:00 sign for ‘Kuranda’
00:14:33:00 the Gadsden travellers enjoy a beer whilst at Kuranda Station

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 157]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows us the wedding of Gwen, one of the Gadsden family.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:10:00 women walking through the garden, dressed-up and smiling at the camera (these are presumably wedding guests arriving)
00:00:19:00 a close up of the bride in a blue wedding dress
00:00:21:00 the following 20 seconds or so of footage is badly under-exposed and very little action can be distinguished
00:00:42:00 the bride and groom pose in front of the church
00:00:54:00 the following 10 seconds or so of footage is badly under-exposed and very little action can be distinguished
00:01:05:00 we see the bride and groom, now dressed in casual clothes, loading-up and settling into a car with a full trailer attached (the car is a distinctive model Ford). Eventually the car drives off, heading through the metal gates of the garden, with the pair smiling and waving at the camera.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 58]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film captures Gadsden family gatherings at the poolside and for a Christmas party at their Toorak, Melbourne home in the 1970s.

There are some great examples of 1970s style fashion trends and hair styles across the generations and a view into the family’s life at home, such as enjoying their backyard pool. Unusually, filmmaker Ron himself is filmed handing out the presents at the Christmas party.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:15:00 scenes of family floating the pool in the family garden
00:00:40:00 an array of fashion of the era
00:00:58:00 a beer moment
00:01:28:00 Ron Gadsden in a 1970s style cravat
00:02:46:00 Ron distributes Christmas presents
00:03:41:00 Jess Gadsden in the pool

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 145]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows yachts sailing around a spot in (most probably) Port Phillip Bay and a school swimming competition.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:04:19:00 yachts racing
00:04:39:00 boats and yachts berthed on the sand
00:04:40:00 single person yachts on the water
00:03:03:00 indoor pool and swimmers
00:03:15:00 students assembling by the pool in readiness for swimming
00:03:18:00 swimmers in competition
00:03:58:00 relay in the pool

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 32]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows the 1977 National Titles skiing competition at Thredbo in NSW.

Members of the Gadsden family were keen skiers and most of this film is taken up with downhill skiing competitions in which the they would take part. The camera captures the speed and difficulty of the downwards skiing in the competition and indecently shows contemporary snowfield fashions.

There are also scenes of the ‘Thredbo Alpine Hotel’ and surrounds including a steaming pool, chalets and mountains in the background, as well as some of the Gadsdens and their cars.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:17:00:00 sign ‘Thredbo Alpine Hotel’

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 133]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film is in two parts. The first shows downhill skiing at Perisher, a large ski resort in the Snowy Mountains of New South Wales. The second, a sports day at ‘Glamorgan’ kindergarten, now the Melbourne ‘prep’ campus of Geelong Grammar.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:00 skiing downhill past camera
00:01:22 skier walking cross country, building in background
00:01:29 child skiing
00:01:43 close up footage of ski lodge verandah
00:01:50 school boys lining up
00:02:03 running and wheelbarrow races on grass
00:02:54 high jump over bar on wooden blocks
00:03:13 closeup female teacher
00:03:17 bean bag race
00:03:48 running race with midway stop to put on painting smock
00:04:21 women and school girls (in hats) watch sports – hats and sunglasses
00:04:29 timekeepers desk
